Since 2−n+1→02^{-n+1} \to 02−n+1→0 (by Theorem 9.7(c) with a=12a = \frac{1}{2}a=21​), there exists NNN such that if n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, then 2−n+1<ε2^{-n+1} < \varepsilon2−n+1<ε. Common Mistakes

The only mistake I saw often was in part (2). Basically, if you write something like this:

No, because by the same argument above, we have

∣sn+k−sn∣<∑i=nn+k−11i,\abs{s_{n+k} - s_n} < \sum_{i=n}^{n+k-1} \frac{1}{i},∣sn+k​−sn​∣<i=n∑n+k−1​i1​,

and the right-hand side diverges, so the result in (1) does not hold.

While nothing you wrote is incorrect, this argument just doesn't answer the question. All this shows is that our proof of (1) no longer works, but doesn't show that the result is false. For instance, what if there's a better proof that works in both cases that we don't know about?

To show that there's no proof possible, you just need to give a counter-example.

Exercise 10.7

Let SSS be a bounded nonempty subset of R\RR such that sup⁡S\sup SsupS is not in SSS. Prove there is a sequence (sn)\p{s_n}(sn​) of points in SSS such that lim⁡n→∞sn=sup⁡S\lim_{n\to\infty} s_n = \sup Slimn→∞​sn​=supS.

Solution.

Let n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N. Then because sup⁡S\sup SsupS is the least upper bound of SSS, sup⁡S−1n\sup S - \frac{1}{n}supS−n1​ cannot be an upper bound for SSS. Thus, there exists sn∈Ss_n \in Ssn​∈S such that

sup⁡S−1n≤sn  ⟹  ∣sn−sup⁡S∣≤1n.\sup S - \frac{1}{n} \leq s_n \implies \abs{s_n - \sup S} \leq \frac{1}{n}.supS−n1​≤sn​⟹∣sn​−supS∣≤n1​.

(Note that I used sn≤sup⁡Ss_n \leq \sup Ssn​≤supS to get the inequality with an absolute value.) Thus, (by the axiom of countable choice) we get a sequence (sn)\p{s_n}(sn​) of elements in SSS such that ∣sn−sup⁡S∣≤1n\abs{s_n - \sup S} \leq \frac{1}{n}∣sn​−supS∣≤n1​. By the squeeze theorem, we immediately get sn→sup⁡Ss_n \to \sup Ssn​→supS.
